text: === graungaard [~graungaar@cpe.atm2-0-73178.0x50a6d452.abnxx10.customer.tele.dk]  has joined #ubuntu

author: ralph
text: catfox: your PATH prefers /usr/local/bin to /usr/bin by design.  Try `echo $PATH'.  Why put python into /usr/local if you don't want to use it?  You could always `chmod -x /usr/local/bin/python'.

author: CircleofChaos
text: When run by root:

author: CircleofChaos
text: smbpasswd [options]  [username]

author: CircleofChaos
text: otherwise:

author: CircleofChaos
text: smbpasswd [options]

author: CircleofChaos
text: options:

author: CircleofChaos
text: -L                   local mode (must be first option)

author: CircleofChaos
text: -h                   print this usage message

author: CircleofChaos
text: -s                   use stdin for password prompt

author: CircleofChaos
text: -c smb.conf file     Use the given path to the smb.conf file

author: CircleofChaos
text: -D LEVEL             debug level

author: CircleofChaos
text: -r MACHINE           remote machine

author: CircleofChaos
text: -U USER              remote username

author: topyli
text: aceb747: maybe his repositories are just b0rken right now

author: CircleofChaos
text: extra options when run by root or in local mode:

author: Subliminal
text: mcphail: like mangled, but when i copied and pasted in here it was in english

author: CircleofChaos
text: -a                   add user

author: CircleofChaos
text: -d                   disable user

author: CircleofChaos

author: Arrghus
text: I have a computer with a 15GB SSD and a 1TB HDD. Would there be any problems with installing Ubuntu on the SSD and using the HDD for file storage (asking because 15GB is below recommended disk size for 16.04.01)?

author: Filystyn
text: but you helped me thank you

author: Filystyn
text: God Bless

author: Arrghus
text: Or is there some other alternative I should know about?

author: guest
text: Arrghus: should be OK, just be aware the automatic partitioning will put a swap partition on the root drive, so you won't have access to the full 15GiB

author: FinalX
text: Arrghus: depends on your setup and what you're using it for. Ubuntu server can be a few hundred MB's, Desktops take a lot more, and if you want to upgrade it's also advisable to have a lot more. You can also mount partitions of the 1TB in system places as well.

author: guest
text: Arrghus: you could use custom partitioning to put the /home directory on the extra drive

author: Arrghus
text: Desktop.

author: sruli
text: Arrghus: if you set your /home partition on the 1tb should work fine (might want to skip the swap or put that on the 1tb too)

author: FinalX
text: on my server I'm using 16.04 on a 16 GB SLC stick, and that uses 4.4 GB now. everything else is on other drives, incl LXC-containers etc.

author: Arrghus
text: Moving /home to the HDD seems sensible.

author: Arrghus
text: Good to know, means I don't have to fiddle around trying to modify the laptop if I want that SSD speed. Thanks people.

text: it should return /usr/bin/python3

author: aryan_

text: you can also check if /usr/lib/python3.5/bz2.py exists .. that's what's installed by the package, libpython3.5-stdlib

author: FinalX
text: hum, that's not a ubuntu python3, then

author: FinalX
text: system's python3 is installed in /usr/bin/python3

author: FinalX
text: dpkg -S /usr/local/bin/python3

author: aryan_
text: FinalX, ok how do I change ?

author: FinalX
text: (if it doesn't return a package, python3 was manually compiled/installed on the system)

author: aryan_
text: to /usr/bin/python3 ?

author: FinalX
text: well, first check if someone screwed up your system by installing software without using packages, or whether you're lucky and it's a package that it's coming from, with the dpkg -S command I gave you

author: FinalX
text: you can also try and just type the full path to the ubuntu version, /usr/bin/python3 and then "import bz2" should work just fine.

author: FinalX
text: if that works you can rename /usr/local/bin/python3 to /usr/local/bin/python3.disabled and if needed, symlink /usr/local/bin/python3 to /usr/bin/python3 .. or uninstall the package if you're lucky enough to have it coming from a package.

text: FinalX, ok, got that my sis installed it via source code

author: aryan_
text: can I uninstall that ??

author: tonyt
text: ducasse k

author: FinalX
text: aryan_: no, if you don't use a package, it's a pain in the butt to get it all removed. maybe you can just do "mv /usr/local/bin/python3 /usr/local/bin/python3.disabled"

author: FinalX
text: then the files will still be there, but your PATH will then probably prefer /usr/bin/python3

author: FinalX
text: I'm assuming the system's python3 is still fully functionally installed

author: ubottu
text: LTS means Long Term Support. Until 12.04 LTS versions of Ubuntu were supported for 3 years on the desktop, and 5 years on the server; since 12.04 (Precise Pangolin) LTS versions will be supported for 5 years on the desktop and server. The latest LTS version of Ubuntu is !Xenial (Xenial Xerus 16.04.1)
